Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Improving capacity for game-based research to scale

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A growing number of educators are looking to game-based learning approaches to increase interest in and understanding of major science mathematics, engineering and technology (STEM) concepts. Serious games have demonstrated the capacity to engage learners in complex domains through role playing and problem solving. A key hypothesis driving many educators' interest in serious games is that they might reach broader scale than previous educational innovations because of their capacity to engage learners, give teachers highly polished learning resources, and provide parents, teachers, administrators and students tools for assessing learning. As examples of empirically-tested game-based learning materials proliferate, the field might benefit by connecting researchers, teachers, developers and policy makers so as to increase the field's capacity to reach scale.

This workshop addresses the need to connect a wide range of experts involved in game development and research to develop and disseminate best practices. The workshop will also establish a network hub where educators and developers can find tools for implementing game-based curricula. Specifically, the project will bring together approximately 100 early contributors, including researchers, teachers, game designers and publishers, to inform the next phases of research, development, and production in the field of games and learning. A closed beta experience will launch in late winter 2013 to support participants preparing for the workshop followed by a public workshop at the annual Games+Learning+Society in June 2013. The goal is to build the basis for a nationwide network of teachers, developers, academics, and industry leaders. If successful, this model will be held at other campuses, including Boston / MIT, Arizona State, and Vanderbilt.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As investments in empirically tested game-based learning continue, there is a growing need to connect researchers, teachers, developers and policy makers in order to increase the capacity for such technologies to reach scale. The major goal of this project is to address this need by creating a national network of educators using game-based learning technologies in their classroom. Such a community can serve as a vehicle for improving upon and expanding innovation in not only STEM educational games but also learning technology research and product development more generally. Toward these ends, we accomplished three goals.

First, we held a two-day workshop held in Madison WI in conjunction with the Games+Learning+Society (GLS) Conference. The first day we convened the advisory board for this project, consisting of master teachers across the nation; the second day we opened to the public and a full day of programming content and networking activities for more than 200 participant teachers.

Second, we refined and launched the online teachers resource entitled Playful Learning (http://www.playfullearning.com/), which connects teachers, educators, academics and researchers who use games-based learning technologies. To date, the online platform now has more than 1,000 registrants and over 120 games featured with complete curricula that have been implemented in classrooms.

Third and finally, we launched a national grassroots network of regional educators Playful Learning Summits across the United States. Since the GLS Conference in June 2013, Playful Learning has been involved in 16 education professional development conferences and workshops, with three more scheduled in the next month, impacting over 1,500 teachers, educators, and administrators. Events have ranged from school-wide events to statewide professional development workshops to regional events such as the Playful Learning Summit at UW-Whitewater (which had 489 registrants). Our Summits are being used as a template to produce similar professional development events across the nation in states such as North Carolina, Massachusetts, Texas, Ohio, Arizona, and beyond. A full list of events can be found at http://beta.playfullearning.com/events.
